name: Perkins Eastman: Chicago Office
field.project_description__project_page:
Perkins Eastman’s Chicago studio brings renewed energy to a historic building. Fully embracing the firm’s Human by Design ethos, employees take advantage of flexible sunlit spaces for easy collaboration or focused individual work. Blending 21st century design ideals with 19th century details, the office features original Rookery Building architectural elements including a window from Burnham and Root’s 11th floor office and a Frank Lloyd Wright elevator gate. Warm wood tones complement the ornate brass of the elevator lobby, which gives way to a massive telescoping glass door that creates a modern entry so employees and visitors feel warmly welcomed.

Setting a standard for adaptive, sustainable design, the office is the first project in the State of Illinois, the fourth in the United States, and one of the first 25 worldwide to obtain WELL™ v2 Platinum Certification. Propelled by guiding principles of WELL, the Perkins Eastman workplace design team collaborated with the Chicago studio to emphasize quality of air, light, sound, thermal comfort, and materials for a workspace that prioritizes well-being and is invigorating and inviting.
field.call_out: Located in the iconic Rookery building, a welcoming, sophisticated workplace puts employee wellness and company culture first.
field.project_description__resume: Programming, architecture, and interior design for the 12,430 sf office renovation in the historic Rookery Building. The workplace received WELL v2 Platinum certification.
field.address: 209 S LaSalle Street Suite 400 Chicago Illinois 60604

name: The Aventiene
field.project_description__project_page:
The Crown is a world-class transit-oriented, peri-urban community of four distinct neighborhoods interconnected by parks, walkable streets, and a nature reserve in close proximity to a state-of-the-art high school and high-quality retail.

Parks and other forms of open spaces consitute more than 40% of the land area and are strategically located so that residents do not have to walk more than one block to access them.

The linear park system, including the nature reserve, along the southern boundary is a major attraction that not only unifies different neighborhoods, but also provides great recreational opportunities for the residents and the surrounding neighborhoods.

The environmental features such as bio-swales, rain gardens, heavily planted “green” streets, LEED certified community buildings, usable roof gardens and environtment-sensitive residential architecture creates unique “branding” for this community.

Investment Strategies: 

Locate land uses compatible with adjacent developments

Extend network of streets to physically link surrounding communities

Dedicate land area to accommodate the Corridor Cities Transitway/ hiker-biker trail system

Public Benefits: 

Better integration of surrounding neighborhoods

Enhanced access to new neighborhood services, education, and transit

Expanded recreational and educational opportunities

Environmental Benefits: 

Reduced circuitious travel routes - more direct access encourages pedestrican and bicycle traffic

Urban Ecosystem where natural habitat coexists with the human habitat

 

A WELL-INTEGRATED COMMUNITY WITHOUT BARRIERS.

The design of street pattern, open space system, and land-use allocation integrates the site with the surrounding communities and promotes co-sharing of neighborhood services, transit, and recreation opportunities. No longer will the surrounding communities have to take circuitous routes to access amenities.
field.call_out: Crown is a world-class transit-oriented community of four distinct neighborhoods interconnected by parks, walkable streets, and a nature reserve in close proximity to a state-of-the-art high school and a new mixed-use commercial district.
field.project_description__resume: A transit-oriented community in close proximity to a state-of-the-art high school, high-quality retail, and a light rail station. Allows for approximately half the population to live within two blocks of the transit station, and more than 70% within walking distance.

name: The Dannon Company
field.project_description__project_page:
Dannon realized that their existing 70,900 sf U.S. corporate office did not meet the particular needs of the firm, nor was it representative of their dynamic company. Seeking to bring a refreshed image and greater productivity to the 280-person office, Dannon sought the assistance of Perkins Eastman to completely renovate the outdated space.

Because the office functions as a marketing tool for Dannon’s products, it not only needs to serve as an efficient workplace but also as a display area that showcases their product line. The existing grid-like, office-based work environment is reengineered into an open-plan space with curved walls that break up the monotony of the office. These walls create pockets in the floor plan that serve as display areas, creating a museum-like experience that seamlessly coexists amidst the everyday functions of an office.

European furnishings, combined with elegant interior treatments that include a muted color palette, maple-wood veneers, white Italian terrazzo tiles, sculptured carpet, sliding glass partitions, and stainless steel and black absolute granite surfaces, establish a modern, forward-thinking office that complements Dannon’s corporate identity.
field.call_out: The office serves as an efficient workplace and as a display area that showcases their product line.
field.address: 100 Hillside Avenue Third Floor White Plains New York 10603

name: Jinan South City
field.project_description__project_page:
Perkins Eastman, in association with its planning affiliate BFJ Planning and landscape affiliate RGR Landscape, developed a framework plan for Jinan South City. This 330-hectare (815-acre) new community is on the southern edge of Jinan, the capital of Shandong Province—an area marked by pristine, undeveloped hills. By integrating these hills into an expansive parks system, the plan for this entirely new city district sought to create urban living within a suburban setting. Numerous picturesque pedestrian trails link the hills with the three neighborhoods and town center, providing the entire community direct access to park land.

This new district in Jinan features 2.8M sm (30 M sf) of residential space, mainly in the form of medium and high-rise structures. Neighborhood-oriented retail and education facilities are located within the two village centers, the larger of which includes a 21,000 sm (226,000 sf) community center complete with athletic facilities and cultural performance venues; one middle and four primary schools; infrastructure that includes utilities and water facilities; and a 10,000 sm (107,000 sf) hospital and 3,000 sm (32,300 sf) clinic.
field.call_out: Numerous picturesque pedestrian trails link the hills with the three neighborhoods and town center, providing the entire community direct access to park land.
field.project_description__resume: Framework plan for an 815-acre new community featuring three neighborhoods and a town center linked by a large central open space that provides important water resources to the city.

name: Weill Cornell Medical College: Cardiology Research Lab
field.project_description__project_page:
After successful collaborations with Weill Medical College of Cornell University for more than 15 years on laboratory and office projects, Perkins Eastman designed an 11,000 sf molecular cardiology research laboratory for the College. The full architectural and interior design services for the renovation were delivered in-house, saving the client money and helping the project to meet completion deadlines.

The renovation provides the school with state-of-the-art wet chemistry and specialty laboratories for cardiology research, offices, and support space. The laboratory design elements include an open modular wet bench lab area created for research and an enclosed core lab comprising tissue culture, microscopy, patch clamp, optical mapping, and an animal procedure room. Laboratory support areas includes a freezer and shared equipment room-built on a floating slab to eliminate vibration in the sensitive adjacent core laboratory space and to ensure accuracy in research and testing. Support spaces also include a cold room, glass wash, a deionized water room, and chemical fume hood alcoves.
field.call_out: The renovation provides the school with state-of-the-art wet chemistry and specialty laboratories for cardiology research, offices, and support space.
field.project_description__resume: "Gut renovation to create 11,000 sf of wet chemistry laboratory and core labs, including tissue culture, microscopy, animal procedure, equipment rooms, faculty offices and support."
field.address: 1300 York Avenue  New York New York 10065

name: NewYork-Presbyterian Queens: West Wing
field.project_description__project_page:
Perkins Eastman designed an upgrade and consolidation of patient care services and created a stronger identity for New York-Presbyterian Queens (formerly New York Hospital Queens).

The original hospital block was comprised of four interconnecting components: the main wing, north wing, ancillary wing, and east wing. The modernization program includes a new five-level, 90,000 sf (8,400 sm) west wing, and selective renovations totaling 30,000 sf (2,800 sm) within the existing buildings. The master plan focuses on two centers of excellence - cardiology and surgery - by increasing the number of critical care beds and enhancing acute care services. Vertical expansion adds four more levels, aligning the addition with the existing buildings.

Through careful planning, all aspects of medical care are designed to be within close proximity of each other. This facilitates patient and staff activities, and permits a more efficient delivery of care, as all levels of medical care are closely connected. Accordingly, the density of the existing buildings increased slightly. The community benefits from this concentration because its residential character remains undisturbed by dispersed satellite facilities.
field.call_out: The master plan focuses on two centers of excellence - cardiology and surgery - by increasing the number of critical care beds and enhancing acute care services.
field.project_description__resume: Master planning and subsequent implementation to create a new five-story west wing for ambulatory surgery, invasive cardiology, 36-bed inpatient orthopedics, support space, and a new building entrance and lobby.

name: Ningbo MT&E Research Institute Master Plan
field.project_description__project_page:
A research campus for Ningbo University, Ningbo Material Technology & Engineering Research Institute is envisioned as a catalyst for sustainable economic development that establishes the city of Ningbo’s importance within the Yangtze-Delta region. Unique to the project is a vision of creating an environment that fosters collaboration between scholarship and industry. Through such collaboration, the institute hoped to inspire students, researchers, and faculty to become leaders in the science and technology field.

Perkins Eastman created a new space that not only encourages this interdisciplinary collaboration and entrepreneurship, but also adheres to environmentally-friendly design principles, while remaining flexible enough to easily accommodate future needs of the institute.

The garden-like campus, with buildings no more than ten stories high in a heavily landscaped environment, is meant to be an inviting public space where sporadic moments of casual interaction abound. This interaction extends into the buildings as well, where innovative plug-and-play laboratory designs allows for a high degree of customization, while bringing different disciplines into close proximity with each other.
field.call_out: The garden-like campus, with buildings no more than ten stories high in a heavily landscaped environment, is meant to be an inviting public space where sporadic moments of casual interaction abound.
field.client: China Ningbo MT & E Res Inst Master
field.project_description__resume: Master planning and design of a 18.2-hectare (45-acre) research campus that combines industry and scholarship into one facility in order to facilitate collaboration.
field.address: Southeast of Zhuangshi Street  Zhenhai, Ningbo

name: NYC School Construction Authority: Mott Haven Campus
field.project_description__project_page:
Composed of four separate schools sharing diverse specialty program spaces, the new Mott Haven Campus of the NYC School Construction Authority (NYCSCA) brings a much needed educational facility to the South Bronx. Housing 2,310 students on a 6.5-acre (2.6 hectare) site, Mott Haven has been recognized as the largest single school construction project in New York City history.

Designed in association with Alexander Gorlin Architects, the Mott Haven Campus marked the emergence of a new facility solution that addresses the growing demand for seats while providing an economy of scale in both capital costs and operational expenses. In response to the proven benefits of “small learning communities,” the design team located the four schools above a podium of shared spaces. With this design, the dining and recreation spaces open onto the field, while the schools face the street, providing a contextual and welcoming front door. Each school continues to function as an independent entity, with distinct color schemes and separate entryways, classrooms, administrative spaces, and dining facilities. A state-of-the-art 600-seat performing arts center acts as the centerpiece of a shared program for the campus and can also be used as the off-hours community theatre.
field.call_out: The Mott Haven campus emerges as an innovative solution to address demand and economy of scale in education with four schools located on a single site.
field.client: New York City School Construction Authority
field.project_description__resume: Design of a 2,200-student campus containing four new schools consisting of two high schools, one intermediate school, one charter school, and a shared 600-seat performing arts center.
field.address: 730 Concourse Village West  Bronx New York 10451

name: Shanghai World Expo 2010
field.project_description__project_page:
The City of Shanghai selected Perkins Eastman as one of three international finalists to plan the city’s World Expo in 2010. The team developed final plan concepts for the 5.28M sm (two square-mile) Expo, which is expected to attract 70 to 100 million visitors-possibly the largest in history. The City has set aside more than 6 kilometers (3.7 miles) on both sides of its downtown riverfront as the future site for this major event.

The Expo’s theme, “Better City, Better Life,” was interpreted by the Perkins Eastman team through the development of a conceptual framework focused on the river, surrounded by a “string of pearls” along which the permanent pavilions and landmark structures would be constructed. The proposed framework for the Expo includes infrastructure, parks, roadways, transportation, and cultural facilities that will guide the development of future neighborhoods in the heart of Shanghai after the Expo concludes.

The Expo is organized into parcels of seven concept cities, each representing new urban paradigms reflecting urban life in the 21st century. The plan is further organized using the framework of the river, and is further articulated with theme pavilions, boulevards, plazas, and landmark structures.

name: Shanghai International Medicine Zone
field.project_description__project_page:
Perkins Eastman led an international team in the preparation of a competition-winning conceptual master plan for an 11,500 sm (4.4 square miles) site designated for the Shanghai International Medical Zone (SIMZ). The northern sector of the SIMZ is the site of a large campus that includes two 500-bed state-of-the-art hospitals, a 7,000-student medical school, a rehabilitation and retirement complex, a medical research park, and an academic exchange center. The southern sector is dedicated to an exhibition, research, and manufacturing zone for medical equipment.

With a dynamic mix of program components totaling more than 465,000 sm (5 million sf), this world-class medical campus serves as a model to guide the rising growth of the healthcare system in Asia. The concept and key organizational structure is based on a landscape with rings of green radiating outward throughout the site. These rings are interwoven with a multi-layered composition of waterways to create a medical garden for a health-based community. This concept affords opportunities to create dramatic architecture and urban clusters within the concentric planning pattern, and synergies which thrive on the garden environment where best practices in medicine, teaching, and research naturally interact.
field.call_out: With a dynamic mix of program components totaling more than 465,000 sm (5 million sf), this world-class medical campus serves as a model to guide the rising growth of the healthcare system in Asia.
field.project_description__resume: "Conceptual master plan for a 2,844-acre site that includes two, 500-bed general hospitals, five specialty hospitals, medical school, research park, and residences for long-term care and assisted living. The site will also feature green design and include housing and amenities for staff and medical students."
field.address: Zhou Kang Area Nan Hui Shanghai
